thread.title: UFC welterweight Viscardi Andrade suspended 2 years for positive steroid test
thread.title_full: UFC welterweight Viscardi Andrade suspended 2 years for positive steroid test

title: UFC welterweight Viscardi Andrade suspended 2 years for positive steroid test
text:
Mar 21, 2017 at 8:54p ET 0Shares 
UFC welterweight and former “Ultimate Fighter: Brazil” competitor Viscardi Andrade has been suspended two years in connection with a positive drug test from March 7, 2016. 
USADA (United States Anti-Doping Agency) announced the suspension on Tuesday. 
“Andrade, 33, tested positive for stanozolol and its metabolites, 16β‐hydroxy‐stanozolol and 3’‐hydroxy‐stanozolol, following an out-of-competition urine test conducted on March 7, 2016,” USADA officials wrote in a statement. “Stanozolol is a non-Specified Substance in the category of Anabolic Agents and is prohibited at all times under the UFC Anti-Doping Policy, which has adopted the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) Prohibited List.” 
Stanozolol is an anabolic steroid and is banned at all times for athletes in and out of competition. As a result of the positive drug test, Andrade now faces a two year sanction. 
Andrade’s suspension was made retroactive to March 20, 2016, which was the day after his most recent fight against Richard Walsh in Australia. Per the UFC’s anti-doping policy, because Andrade’s drug test was taken ahead of his fight the promotion holds the right to disqualify him and nullify the results of the bout. 
Andrade was victorious against Walsh but the UFC could strip him of the win and declare the fight a no contest, but that decision hasn’t been made as of yet. 
Based on the date of his suspension, Andrade would be eligible to return to action after March 20, 2018.
